misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (grade calculator vs. distance formula)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a distance calculator between two points instead of a grade-to-letter converter, indicating a misunderstanding or misreading of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I think the task is to read coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2), compute the distance between two points using the distance formula, and print that distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read a single numeric grade from 0 to 100, then use conditional statements to determine which letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) corresponds to that number, and print the letter grade.
symptoms: All variable names and prompts refer to x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade.
The program computes a square root expression for distance instead of using conditional logic.
The output describes the distance between two points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or focused on a previous distance-formula problem and did not adjust their approach to match the grade-calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Identify the required inputs (one grade), the processing (checking which range it falls into with if/else-if/else), and the exact output format ("Letter grade: X"). Then design your code around that specification.
related_concepts: Designing conditionals based on numeric ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and output are focused on computing distance between two points, with no trace of grade input or letter-grade logic, strongly indicating a misinterpretation of the assignment.

evidence.note: The code reads coordinates, computes distance, and prints a distance message instead of reading a single grade and printing a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a solution for a different programming problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator assignment. The submission fails to implement the necessary input prompts, conditional logic (if/else if/else), or output structure required for Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the provided code fulfills the requirements of the Grade Calculator task (Q3).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The Grade Calculator task requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using a chain of conditional statements (if/else if/else) to map that score to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Program input requests coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade.
Program performs distance formula calculation instead of grade comparison.
Program output is a distance value, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to correctly read, understand, or address the specified problem prompt Q3, likely due to submitting the code for an unrelated problem or misunderstanding the task entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the specified requirements for Q3. The correct solution must read only one grade and use if/else logic to print 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D', or 'F'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is an unambiguous implementation of the distance formula, which is entirely irrelevant to the Grade Calculator problem statement.

evidence.note: The inputs read four coordinates for distance calculation, not the single numeric grade required by the rubric for Q3.

evidence.snippet:
double d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: The core logic performs the distance formula calculation and prints the distance, completely omitting the required conditional logic for grade assignment and the letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code for a distance calculator between two points, not a grade calculator as required by the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a different problem - calculating the Euclidean distance between two coordinate points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade value
Code calculates distance using the distance formula instead of performing grade range comparisons
Program output is 'The distance of the two points is [value]' instead of 'Letter grade: [A/B/C/D/F]'
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misunderstanding of the problem requirements. The student either read the wrong problem, copied code from a different assignment, or fundamentally misunderstood what was being asked.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. The task requires: (1) reading ONE integer/double representing a grade, (2) using if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) printing the corresponding letter grade. Start over with the correct problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (distance calculator) rather than the required grade calculator. This is not a minor logic error but a fundamental misalignment with the assignment requirements.

evidence.note: Reading four coordinate values instead of one grade value as required
Using distance formula instead of grade range conditionals

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Output format is for distance calculator, not grade calculator

misconceptions.name: Implemented a distance calculator instead of a grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that reads coordinates for two points and computes the distance between them, instead of reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is to read two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and compute the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user and then, using conditional statements, print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Input prompts refer to x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade.
The program reads four double values instead of one numeric grade.
There are no conditional statements (if/else) to handle grade ranges.
The output message describes the distance between two points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements, likely confusing this task with a different assignment about computing distance between two points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and redesign the program so it reads a single grade value and uses if/else-if/else statements to check which range (90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, below 60) it falls into, then prints the appropriate letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, variable names, prompts, and output are clearly for a distance formula task and do not reference grades or letter grading at all.

evidence.note: This code reads four coordinates and computes the distance between two points instead of reading a single grade and mapping it to a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program (distance calculator) that is completely unrelated to the assigned task (Grade Calculator). This indicates a complete failure to understand or attempt the required problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task was to calculate the distance between two points, or they submitted the wrong code file entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required creating a grade calculator based on numeric input and conditional logic (if/else if/else). The distance formula calculation is incorrect for this problem.
symptoms: Code calculates distance between two points instead of calculating a letter grade.
Input prompts ask for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
Output reports 'The distance...' instead of 'Letter grade...'
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt, submitting the wrong solution file, or fundamental inability to match code implementation to stated requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem description for Q3 carefully. The task is to read a single integer grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine and output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely for a different problem (distance formula), confirming a complete mismatch with the assignment requirements (Grade Calculator).

evidence.note: The entire implementation is a distance calculator, not a grade calculator, violating all requirements.

misconceptions.name: Solving Wrong Problem
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have either submitted code from a different assignment or fundamentally misunderstood the assignment requirements. The submission is a distance calculator (computing Euclidean distance between two points) rather than a grade calculator.
misconceptions.student_belief: The assignment requires reading two coordinate pairs and calculating the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges: A=90-100, B=80-89, C=70-79, D=60-69, F=<60.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates instead of a grade
Program calculates and outputs distance instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
Sample run is ignored entirely
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either submitted code from a different assignment or did not carefully read the problem statement and sample run.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully review the assignment requirements. Write a new program that: (1) reads a single integer/double grade from 0-100, (2) uses if-else statements to check which range it falls into, and (3) outputs the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the submitted code solves an entirely different problem with no overlap in logic or output with the grade calculator requirements.

evidence.note: The program reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade value. This is incompatible with the grade calculator assignment.

evidence.snippet:
double d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: The program calculates and outputs Euclidean distance, not a letter grade. This shows the student is solving a distance calculator problem.
